WorkItem.ClosedComment:
There is the community site referenced below as a solution currently.  Closing this issue on the 'issue tracker' section now, as it's not a 'product bug' as such.  If there is further discussion to be had please open a thread on the 'discussions' section.

Thanks!

 - Bill
WorkItem.Description: I'm suggesting the creation of an official community site, or even a github/codeplex site, where people can submit and collaborate on the .d definition files. Ultimately I think having a central resource to share and collaborate on these files will be better than having them spread across multiple sites/repositories. Of course getting the API owners to generate .d.ts files themselves would be great, I just don't see this happening any time soon.

Comments.Message: Agreed, ideally with distribution through some sort of package management.
Thanks for the suggestion! Assigning to Jonathan who is handling our suggestions.
Good idea - we are already banging up against the limitations of not having a .d file for JQueryUI
I would think NuGet would support .d.ts files and inclusion in projects better than a distinct site? This would also permit different versions of each .d.ts file.

I would say that this would be the responsiblity of the library developers and the community. Ideally distributed through their websites and/or through a package manager, such as NuGet. 

I therefore say that this isn't up to Microsoft unless they also want to distribute it through the the TypeScript website.

For now you can use/contribute to the following GitHub project of type definitions for popular JavaScript libraries.

https://github.com/borisyankov/DefinitelyTyped

> The project aims to provide high quality definitions for the most popular libraries out there.

I have contacted Boris (who owns DefinitelyTyped) and I will be working on a set of powershell build scripts for him to generate definition NuGet packages which take dependencies on their targeted libraries (also NuGet packages).
